docs.snippet: There is, no doubt, a class of men among as there may be in the Government who have a vague expectation of a final separation between the North and the South, and who begin to think a peaceable dissolution would be better than this waste of wealth,...
docs.lead_paragraph: There is, no doubt, a class of men among as there may be in the Government who have a vague expectation of a final separation between the North and the South, and who begin to think a peaceable dissolution would be better than this waste of wealth, this slow destruction of property and business.

headline.main: HIGHLY IMPORTANT NEWS.; THE ENGAGEMENT NEAR MARTINSBURGH. Official Report of Maj.-Gen. Patterson. TEN THOUSAND REBELS ROUTED. Three of the National Forces Killed and Ten Wounded. HOW GEN. SCOTT RECEIVED THE NEWS. Preparations for the Advance Towards Manassas Junction. The Troops Being Formed into Brigades. Gen. Frement to Command the Great Western Movement. The New Legislature of Virginia in Session. Recognition by the National Government. Preparations for Celebrating the 4th. THE FIGHT NEAR MARTINSBURGH. THE KILLED AND WOUNDED. KILLED. SPECIAL DISPATCH FROM WASHINGTON SENATORIAL CAUCUS. THE TWENTY-FOURTH ARRIVED. THE PARADE ON THE FOURTH. GUARD IN THE PUBLIC BUILDINGS. B EN. WOOD IN BAD ODOR. A POST-OFFICE ROBBER. CELEBRATING THE FOURTH. A HORSE STORY. FOUR REBELS KILLED. REVIEWED BY THE PRESIDENT. A LARGE ARCH. WEST POINTERS AS DRILL-OFFICERS. A MEMBER FROM NORTH CAROLINA. MR. COLFAX WITHDRAWN. SOUTH CAROLINIANS GONE HOME. ILLNESS OF MRS. MARSTEN. FORMING BRIGADES. WANT OF SHOES. NO DISPATCHES FROM FRANCE. A SHORT SESSION. THE MOV
